data.title: Feature Request: `auto_find_in_selection` option
data.body:
On 12 Jul, I opened issue #9120 because VSCode got the behavior that `find in selection` is **off** by default if I press `ctrl+F` with a multiline selection. Then it was fixed soon at that time.
But now, VSCode got the behavior again in v1.7.1 because of #12109.

I prefer that `find in selection` is **on** by default if I press `ctrl+F` with a multiline selection.
I know some IDE/editors are behaving so.

- Visual Studio 2013
- eclipse
- Sublime Text

In Sublime Text case, it has `auto_find_in_selection` option. I can switch the behavior.
I think good if Visual Studio Code also has the option to configure the behavior.

Thank you.

data.title: Debug Toolbar invisible, Shortcuts for debugging not working
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: Kubuntu 16.04.1 LTS

Since I updated my VSCode to 1.7.1 yesterday my debugging process is kinda buggy. Everytime I run (not debug!, Ctrl+F5) my application, the application is run but I don't see the debug toolbar. Besides that I also can't use my debug hotkeys to start/stop the application. What's weird about this is that as soon as I type anything into my debug console the debug toolbar gets visible and the debug hotkeys get usable again. 
I'm working with Python, therefore I'm using [this](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=donjayamanne.python) extension.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Run any Application. Default shortcut: Ctrl + F5

**UPDATE**

I tried to completely reinstall VSCode now, which didn't work unfortunately. I still had that bug.
After uninstalling VSCode 1.7.1 and reinstalling VSCode 1.6.1 it works again. So I am pretty sure it has to do something with the new Version 1.7.1.

data.title: IntelliSense completion list is inaccurate
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 x64

Vscode fails to display IntelliSense of object`s property when the object's property name is more than one character. In the case when I use type define  as below.

Steps to Reproduce:

First, in index.d.ts, I define a function called test
``` typescript
// index.d.ts
export function test<Obj>(oldV: Obj, newV : Obj): string

```

Then, I use `test` function  in action.js. 
I pass a object with one-character and multi-character props to test , as follow
```typescript
// action.js
import { test } from './index'

let testObj = {
  a: 1,
  bb: 2
}

test(testObj, {
  //TODO
})

```
When I input `a`  at `//TODO`, IntelliSense runs well, as follow : 
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10753131/20089964/26427b5a-a5c5-11e6-82f0-a6a3905306fe.png)

But when I input `b`  at `//TODO`, IntelliSense fails to parse 'bb' as a property of testObj : 
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10753131/20090300/59c8d580-a5c7-11e6-8a5d-98e9253000fb.png)


Am I mistakenly writing index.d.ts, or are there some bugs with vscode ?

data.title: Formatting code
data.body:
- VSCode Version:1.7.1
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1.  When opening up files like XML or C#, the code is highlighted nicely, but there is no way to format the code.  Other types, like JS files allow me to to do a **format document** or **format selection**.  What is the secret to allowing me to format other file types?

data.title: Unable to update extensions: "Command 'Extensions: Update All Extensions' is not enabled in the current context."
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: Windows 10 14393

I was unable to update any of my extensions after I updated to 1.7.1. Trying to execute "ext update" from the command palette I was prompted with "Command 'Extensions: Update All Extensions' is not enabled in the current context." And the command in contextual menu was grey and not clickable.
Googled the error message but there seems to be  no relevant mentions.

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Press F1 to bring up command palette and type "ext update" and choose " Update all extensions".
2. Click the "..." button on the extension tab and the command in the contextual menu is grey.

data.title: Assign a quit command from Ctrl+Q or Ctrl+Shift+Q
data.body:
VSCode Version: 
```
Version 1.7.1
Commit 02611b40b24c9df2726ad8b33f5ef5f67ac30b44
Date 2016-11-03T13:46:46.244Z
Shell 1.3.8
Renderer 52.0.2743.82
Node 6.5.0
```

**OS Version:** Arch Linux (w/ testing repo, up to date as of this very second)

**Steps to Reproduce:**
1. Press `Ctrl-Q` or `Ctrl-Shift-Q`

**Expected**: VS Code exits.

**Actual**: VS Code does not exit.

I tried to peak around. The other relevant open issue seemed to be more related to editor-specific keyboard shortcuts whereas this seems like an OS-integration issue.

I don't know if this should work on Windows, but it was something that basically every other app I use on Linux conforms to.

data.title: Warning "Invalid abbreviation" in "Jade" Language Mode
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.7.1 (02611b40b24c9df2726ad8b33f5ef5f67ac30b44, 2016-11-03T13:53:14.822Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 6.3.9600
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|html-snippets|abusaidm|0.0.16|
|npm-intellisense|christian-kohler|0.1.3|
|jquerysnippets|donjayamanne|0.0.1|
|live-html-previewer|hdg|0.0.1|
|vscode-jade-snippets|mrmlnc|1.0.1|
|ejs-language-support|QassimFarid|0.0.1|
|bootstrap-3-snippets|wcwhitehead|0.0.7|
|JavaScriptSnippets|xabikos|1.1.0|

---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a new jade/pug document (e.g. test.pug or test.jade)
2. Ensure language mode is "Jade"
3. Type the vertical bar (pipe | ) character into the document
4. Press tab
5. Warning message is displayed and tab is **not** inserted.

Message is shown on pressing tab. "|{tab}" is a valid operation in jade and is used in cases like the example below:

```jade
button(ng-click='addUser()').btn.btn-primary
    i.ion-plus-round
    |   Add new user
```

data.title: Close folder does not clear the backup workspace path
data.body:
Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open VS Code on a path
2. Close the folder
3. Check `<userdatadir>/Backups/workspaces.json`, the path that was closed should have been removed in step 2. This will cause unexpected window restores.

data.title: Closing the last window behaves inconsistently (hot-exit)
data.body:
I think closing the last window should behave the same as closing a second-to-last window. Either they both preserve dirty editor states or both ask whether the dirty states should be saved or discarded.

Having mixed behavior is bound to confuse the user. (Same goes for exiting the app when there are multiple windows.)

Maybe there should be a setting for "preserve dirty editor state on close/exit" (better name TBD). Dirty editor state should always be preserved on: Reload Window, Restart to Update, crashes.

data.title: Background color highlighting drawn incorrectly
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.7.1 (02611b40b24c9df2726ad8b33f5ef5f67ac30b44, 2016-11-03T13:46:00.226Z)
- OS Version: Darwin x64 16.1.0
- Extensions:

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|

![screen shot 2016-11-07 at 16 27 27](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/158981/20076608/1d6556f6-a507-11e6-9dd6-e1b5283c7afb.png)

---

Background color highlighting in the editor is broken in dark themes. There are chunks of the screen that are lighter than the background color set in the theme. This is also present in lighter themes (like the built-in Solarized light), but in light themes it is much less noticeable. Notice in the screenshot the highlight problems in the editor window, as well as the file selector sidebar. 

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set VS code to use built-in solarized dark or dark+ theme.
2. Observe behavior.

data.title: Unexpected js code format behaviour
data.body: - VSCode Version: 1.7.1 - OS Version: ``` NAME="Ubuntu" VERSION="16.04.1 LTS (Xenial Xerus)" ID=ubuntu ID_LIKE=debian PRETTY_NAME="Ubuntu 16.04.1 LTS" VERSION_ID="16.04" HOME_URL="http://www.ubuntu.com/" SUPPORT_URL="http://help.ubuntu.com/" BUG_REPORT_URL="http://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/" VERSION_CODENAME=xenial UBUNTU_CODENAME=xenial ``` Steps to Reproduce: 1. Create a file called test.js 2. Past this code `return {amount} fixes;` 3. Press `Ctrl+Shift+I` to format the code. Then we have `return {amount}fixes;` (the white space between `{amount}` and `fixes` was removed). Why?

data.title: Get Line Home with WordWrap

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
**Version**
- VSCode Version: 1.7.1
- OS Version: Fedora, 24

**Feature Request**

Enable home key to go to start of the line (column 0), even with word-wrapping.

**How To Reproduce**
1. Configure "settings.json" to use the following rules: `"editor.wordWrap": true`, and  `"editor.wrappingColumn": 80`
2. Add `Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipiscing elit. Phasellus sit amet semper erat, ut posuere.` as text to the editor, and ensure word wrap is active.
3. Set the cursor at the end of the line (Line 1, col 101).
4. Press `Home` key twice. First press has the expected behavior (cursor goes to start of the wrapped line, or col 77), second press does not move the cursor (when it should go to col 0).
